Topic.Title: "AMD soars, analyst cites speculation on consoles"

Message.Msg: There is only one fact. Share price. Its all that matters. You can only bring price to the bank. U cant bring fundamental news, u cant bring speculation to the bank. Some say price and volume. But no. U can't even bring volume to the bank. Only price pays. In this regard, Xc is more right recently. AMD doubled since its $1.8 low. Impressive. Yes bankruptcy risk it has. But we could all put some trading $ into it to enjoy it.

Message.Title: Nvidia Kai, Nvidia phoenix !
Message.Msg: What ever happened to Nvidia kai tablets? Fudzilla had an old article on this. Google search. It is proven til today. Said kai was supposed to offer vendors a cheap tegra 3 for cheap tablets. I was hopeful then it could sell tens of millions with Google then others jumping over it. Turns out as per the article, that with Google nexus 7, no other vendors will try it. 2 problems surfaced. One, nexus only sell ok amounts , and two, we are losing the spot to qcom. Hence, kai has failed. So, this was a sound good idea, but failed in a few months. Then Nvidia announced project Phoenix phones. The fact is, based on history, looks like this could turn out to be like kai again. I believe the problem is Nvidia likes big promising ideas. It is their culture. They always talk about promising future, hence once kai seems to meet roadblocks, they do not find ways to overcome it. In the end, mediatek quietly replaced kai. Acer and Nvidia used to work closely. But their latest 8 inch tablet , a cheap one will be using mediateks! Nvidia core business is fine. Hence it is unlikely to crash. But it lacks serious winning ideas that will propel earnings. My wish is that they go to their core competency. Hyping. Hype an idea that is like project Denver then push up share price big to $26, then crash it down when people realize its hype. Just give me a rally and that will be fun. However, even this they may run into problem. Cos recall insider trading case against it. I guess with that charge, stock operators dare not touch it. So .... In the end, could still end up no better than watching paints dry.
Kai = Nexus 7.

Dude,, I know. Did u read carefully? But just one nexus 7. Other vendors shun it. And only one generation. Next generation? Gone. You call this a success? Ok success yes, but no runaway. I also talked about acer. Read it. In the end , Nvidia hype kai. Loud loud loud. Mediatek? Quiet. But quietly doing its work. Taking kai businesses away from Nvidia. Barking dogs dun bite, the quiet ones does! Lol
Hey sparky, speaking of barking, can you please shut up with your blather! Now go take a walk and be a good boy for once.

Topic.Title: IDC on global tablet shipments Q1 2013: IPads share dropped from 58% to 39.6%; ASUS passed AMZN as #3

Message.Msg: What tablet does BRCM power.. I would like to know, tool

If Qualcomm bought AMD it would primarily be for the x86 and all the patents/architects that went with it. Krait is all right but it is a bit of a lightweight core, they could do with more cpu expertise and with an x86 core they could attack the Windows market properly. Of course the ATI gpu biz would be a bonus but would not be the main reason IMO. Yeah, Qualcomm buying AMD makes sense to me too but for different reasons.

If Qualcomm bought AMD, then I would probably become a fair bit more bearish on Intel. Honestly, Intel should just buy them to prevent x86 patents from falling into the wrong hands and potentially causing some seriously negative issues re: x86-64 for Intel.
Intel can't buy AMD never mind what the silly current rumor says, the FTC, EU etc won't allow it. The failure of WindowsRT means the ARM anti-monopoly argument won't wash in the PC market.

I would buy either AMD or IT(including the MIPS processors) in a heartbeat if I was Qualcomm's CEO as they easily have the cash and they need their cpu/gpu IP reinforcing in the long run against the stiff competition heading their way from Intel and maybe even Nvidia if Project Denver is any good. Apple and Intel's shares of Imagination Technologies rules that out leaving AMD. Qualcomm could afford to maintain uncompetitive AMD cpu/gpu generations until better ones were developed.

Don't think Intel would acquire AMD either, not just because of regulatory hurdles. In the opinion of many, myself included, AMD would not add significantly to Intel's core competences, especially in the context of Intel's future strategies, as indicated by the recent appointments of Brian Krzanich and Renee James - chip manufacturing and software will be two of the major focuses.
ibexx, Agreed.
